div.head: THE CONSTITUTION OF NEW-JERSEY.
div.p: WHEREAS all the con≈øtitutional authority, ever po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed by the kings of Great Britain, over the≈øe Colonies, or their other dominions, was, by compact, derived from the people, and held of them, for the common intere≈øt of the whole ≈øociety; allegiance and protection are, in the nature of things, reciprocal ties, each equally depending upon the other, and liable to be di≈ø≈øolved by the other's being refu≈øed or withdrawn: and whereas George the Third, king of Great-Britain, has refu≈øed protection to the good people of the≈øe Colonies; and by a≈ø≈øenting to ≈øundry acts of the Briti≈øh parliament, attempted to ≈øubject them to the ab≈øolute dominion of that body; and has al≈øo made war upon them, in the mo≈øt cruel and unnatural manner, for no other cau≈øe than a≈ø≈øerting their ju≈øt rights; all civil authority under him is nece≈ø≈øarily at an end, and a di≈ø≈øolution of government in each Colony has con≈øequently taken place.

And whereas, in the pre≈øent deplorable ≈øituation of the≈øe Colonies, expo≈øed to the fury of a cruel and relentle≈øs enemy, ≈øome form of government is ab≈øolutely nece≈ø≈øary, not only for the pre≈øervation of good order, but al≈øo the more effectually to unite the people, and enable them to exert their whole force in their own nece≈ø≈øary defence; and as the honourable the Continental Congre≈øs, the ≈øupreme council of the American Colonies, has advi≈øed ≈øuch of the Colon ‚Ä¢ es as have not yet gone into the mea≈øure, to adopt, for them≈øelves re≈øpectively, ≈øuch government as ≈øhall be≈øt conduce to their own happine≈øs and ≈øafety, and the wellbeing of America in general:‚ÄîWe, the Repre≈øentatives of the Colony of New-Jer≈øey, having been elected by all the counties in the free≈øt manner, and in Congre≈øs a≈ø≈øembled,
have, after mature deliberations, agreed upon a ≈øet of charter rights and the form of a Con≈øtitution, in manner following, viz.
I. That the government of this Province ≈øhall be ve≈øted in a Governor, Legi≈ølative Council, and General A≈ø≈øembly.

II. That the Legi≈ølative Council, and General A≈ø≈øembly, ≈øhall be cho≈øen, for the fir≈øt time, on the ≈øecond Tue≈øday in Augu≈øt next; the members whereof ≈øhall be the ≈øame in number and qualifications as are herein after mentioned; and ≈øhall be and remain ve≈øted with all the powers and authority to be hold by any future Legi≈ølative Council and A≈ø≈øembly of this Colony, until the ≈øecond Tue≈øday in October, which ≈øhall be in the year of our Lord one thou≈øand ≈øeven hundred and ≈øeventy-≈øeven.

III. That on the ≈øecond Tue≈øday in October yearly, and every year forever (with the privilege of adjourning from day to day, as occa≈øion may require) the counties ≈øhall ≈øeverally choo≈øe one per≈øon, to be a member of the Legi≈ølative Council of this Colony, who ≈øhall be, and have been, for one whole year next before the election, an inhabitant and freeholder in the county in which he is cho≈øen, and worth at lea≈øt one thou≈øand pounds proclamation money, of real and per≈øonal e≈øtate, within the ≈øame county: that, at the ≈øame time, each county ≈øhall al≈øo choo≈øe three members of A≈ø≈øembly; provided that no per≈øon ≈øhall be entitled to a ≈øeat in the ≈øaid A≈ø≈øembly unle≈øs he be, and have been, for one whole year next before the election, an inhabitant of the county he is to repre≈øent, and worth five hundred pounds proclamation money, in real and per≈øonal e≈øtate, in the ≈øame county: that on the ≈øecond Tue≈øday next after the day of election, the Council and A≈ø≈øembly ≈øhall ≈øeparately meet; and that the con≈øent of both Hou≈øes ≈øhall be nece≈ø≈øary to every law; provided, that ≈øeven ≈øhall be a quorum of the Council, for doing bu≈øine≈øs, and that no law ≈øhall pa≈øs, unle≈øs ther ‚Ä¢ be a majority of all the Repre≈øentatives of each body per≈øonally pre≈øent, and agreeing thereto. Provided always, that if a majority of the Repre≈øentatives of this Province, in Council and General A≈ø≈øembly convened, ≈øhall, at any time or times hereafter, judge it equitable and proper, to add to or dimini≈øh the number or proportion of the members of A≈ø≈øembly for any
county or counties in this Colony, then, and in ≈øuch ca≈øe, the ≈øame may, on the principles of more equal repre≈øentation, be lawfully done; any thing in this Charter to the contrary notwith≈øtanding: ≈øo that the whole number of Repre≈øentatives in A≈ø≈øembly ≈øhall not, at any time, be le≈øs than thirty-nine.

IV. That all inhabitants of this Colony, of full age, who are worth fifty pounds proclamation money, clear e≈øtate in the ≈øame, and have re≈øided within the county in which they claim a vote for twelve months immediately preceding the election, ≈øhall be entitled to vote for Repre≈øentatives in Council and A≈ø≈øembly; and al≈øo for all other public officers, that ≈øhall be elected by the people of the county at large.

V. That the A≈ø≈øembly, when met, ≈øhall have power to choo≈øe a Speaker, and other their officers; to be judges of the qualifications and elections of their own members; ≈øit upon their own adjournments; prepare bills, to be pa≈ø≈øed into laws; and to empower their Speaker to convene them, whenever any extraordinary occurrence ≈øhall render it nece≈ø≈øary.

VI. That the Council ≈øhall al≈øo have power to prepare bills to pa≈øs into laws, and have other like powers as the A≈ø≈øembly, and in all re≈øpects be a free and independent branch of the Legi≈ølature of this Colony; ≈øave only, that they ≈øhall not prepare or alter any money bill‚Äîwhich ≈øhall be the privilege of the A≈ø≈øembly: that the Council ≈øhall, from time to time, be convened by the Governor or Vice-Pre≈øident, but mu≈øt be convened, at all times, when the A≈ø≈øembly ≈øits; for which purpo≈øe the Speaker of the Hou≈øe of A≈ø≈øembly ≈øhall always, immediately after an adjournment, give notice to the Governor, or Vice-Pre≈øident, of the time and place to which the Hou≈øe is adjourned.

VII. That the Council and A≈ø≈øembly jointly, at their fir≈øt meeting after each annual election, ≈øhall, by a majority of votes, elect ≈øome fit per≈øon within the Colony, to be Governor for one year, who ≈øhall be con≈øtant Pre≈øident of the Council, and have a ca≈øting ‚Ä¢ ote in their proceedings; and that the Council them≈øelves ≈øhall choo≈øe a Vice Pre≈øident, who ≈øhall act as ≈øuch in the ab≈øence of the Governor.

VIII. That the Governor, or, in his ab≈øence, the Vice-Pre≈øident of the Council, ≈øhall have the ≈øupreme executive power, be Chancellor of the Colony, and act as captaingeneral and commander in chief of all the militia, and other military force in this Colony; and that any three or more of the Council ≈øhall, at all times, be a privy-council, to con≈øult them; and that the Governor be ordinary or ≈øurrogate general.

IX. That the Governor and Council, (≈øeven whereof ≈øhall be a quorum) be the Court of Appeals, in the la≈øt re≈øort, in all clau≈øes of law, as heretofore; and that they po≈ø≈øe≈øs the power of granting pardons to criminals, after condemnation, in all ca≈øes of trea≈øon, felony, or other offences.
X. That captains, and all other inferior officers of the militia, ≈øhall be cho≈øen by the companies, in the re≈øpective counties; but field and general officers, by the Council and A≈ø≈øembly.

XI. That the Council and A≈ø≈øembly ≈øhall have power to make the Great Seal of this Colony, which ≈øhall be kept by the Governor, or, in his ab≈øence, by the Vice-Pre≈øident of the Council, to be u≈øed by them as occa≈øion may require: and it ≈øhall be called, The Great Seal of the Colony of New-Jer≈øey.

XII. That the Judges of the Supreme Court ≈øhall continue in orfice for ≈øeven years: the Judges of the Inferior Court of Common Pleas in the ≈øeveral counties, Ju≈øtices of the Peace, Clerks of the Supreme Court, Clerks of the Inferior Court of Common Pleas and Quarter Se≈ø≈øions, the Attorney-General, and Provincial Secretary, ≈øhall continue in office for five years: and the Provincial Trea≈øurer ≈øhall continue in office for one year; and that they ≈øhall be ≈øeverally appointed by the Council and A≈ø≈øembly, in manner afore≈øaid, and commi≈ø≈øioned by the Governor, or, in his ab≈øence, the Vice-Pre≈øident of the Council. Provided always, that the ≈øaid officers, ≈øeverally, ≈øhall be capable of being re-appointed, at the end of the terms ≈øeverally before limited; and that any of the ≈øaid officers ≈øhall be liable to be di≈ømi≈ø≈øed, when adjudged guilty of mi≈øbehaviour, by the Council, on an impeachment of the A≈ø≈øembly.

XIII. That the inhabitants of each county, qualified to vote as afore≈øaid, ≈øhall at the time and place of electing
their Repre≈øentatives, annually elect one Sheriff, and one or more Coroners; and that they may re-elect the ≈øame per≈øon to ≈øuch offices, until he ≈øhall have ≈øerved three years, but no longer; after which, three years mu≈øt elap≈øe before the ≈øame per≈øon is capable of being elected again. When the election is certified to the Governor, or Vice-Pre≈øident, under the hands of fix freeholders of the county for which they were elected, they ≈øhall be immediately commi≈ø≈øioned to ≈øerve in their re≈øpective offices.

XIV. That the town≈øhips, at their annual town meetings for electing other officers, ≈øhall choo≈øe con≈øtanbles for the di≈øtricts re≈øpectively; and al≈øo three or more judicious freeholders of good character, to hear and finally determine all appeals, relative to unju≈øt a≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øments, in ca≈øes of public taxation; which commi≈ø≈øioners of appeal ≈øhall, for that purpo≈øe, ≈øit at ≈øome ≈øuitable time or times, to be by them appointed, and made known to the people by adverti≈øements.

XV. That the laws of the Colony ≈øhall begin in the following ≈øtyle, viz. "Be it enacted by the Council and General A≈ø≈øembly of this Colony, and it is hereby enacted by authority of the ≈øame:" that all commi≈ø≈øions, granted by the Governor or Vice-Pre≈øident, ≈øhall run thus‚Äî"The Colony of New-Jer≈øey to A. B. &c. greeting:" and that all writs ≈øhall likewi≈øe run in the name of the Colony: and that all indictments ≈øhall conclude in the following manner, viz. "Again≈øt the peace of this Colony, the government and dignity of the ≈øame."
XVI. That all criminals ≈øhall be admitted to the ≈øame privileges of witne≈ø≈øes and coun≈øel, as their pro≈øecutors are or ≈øhall be entitled to.

XVII. That the e≈øtates of ≈øuch per≈øons as ≈øhall de≈øtroy their own lives, ≈øhall not, for that offence, be for≈øeited; but ≈øhall de≈øcend in the ≈øame manner, as they would have done, had ≈øuch per≈øons died in the natural way; nor ≈øtall any article, which may occa≈øion accidentally the death of any one, be henceforth deemed a deodand: or in any wi≈øe for≈øeited, on account of ≈øuch misfortune.

XVIII. That no per≈øon ≈øhall ever, within this Colony, be deprived of the ine≈øtimable privilege of wor≈øhipping Almighty God in a manner agreeable to the dictates of his
own con≈øcience; nor, under any pretence whatever, be compelled to attend any place of wor≈øhip, contrary to his own faith and judgment; nor ≈øhall any per≈øon, within this Colony, ever be obliged to pay tithes, taxes, or any other rates, for the purpo≈øe of building or repairing any other church or churches, place or places of wor≈øhip, or for the maintenance of any mini≈øter or mini≈øtry, contrary to what he believes to be right, or has deliberately or voluntarily engaged him≈øelf to perform.

XIX. That there ≈øhall be no e≈øtabli≈øhment of any one religious ≈øect in this Province, in preference to another; and that no Prote≈øtant inhabitant of this Colony ≈øhall be denied the enjoyment of any civil right, merely on account of his religious principles; but that all per≈øons, profe≈ø≈øing a belief in the faith of any Prote≈øtant ≈øect, who ≈øhall demean them≈øelves peaceably under the government, as hereby e≈øtabli≈øhed, ≈øhall be capable of being elected into any office of profit or tru≈øt, or being a member of either branch of the Legi≈ølature, and ≈øhall fully and freely enjoy every privilege and immunity, enjoyed by others their fellow ≈øubjects.

XX. That the legi≈ølative department of this government may, as much as po≈ø≈øible, be pre≈øerved from all ≈øu≈øpicion of corruption, none of the Judges of the Supreme or other Courts, Sheriffs, or any other per≈øon or per≈øons po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed of any po≈øt of profit under the government, other than Ju≈øtices of the Peace, ≈øhall be entitled to a ≈øeat in the A≈ø≈øembly; but that, on his being elected, and taking his ≈øeat, his office or po≈øt ≈øhall be con≈øidered as vacant.

XXI. That all the laws of this Province, contained in the edition lately publi≈øhed by Mr. Al ‚Ä¢ in≈øon, ≈øhall be and remain in full force, until altered by the Legi≈ølature of this Colony (≈øuch only excepted, as are incompatible with this Charter) and ≈øhall be, according as heretofore, regarded in all re≈øpects, by all civil officers, and others, the good people of this Province.

XXII. That the common law of England, as well as ≈øo much of the ≈øtatute law, as have been heretofore practi≈øed in this Colony, ≈øhall ≈øtill remain in force, until they ≈øhall be altered by a future law of the Legi≈ølature; ≈øuch parts only excepted, as are repugnant to the rights and privileges contained in this Charter; and that the ine≈øtimable
right of trial by jury ≈øhall remain confirmed as a part of the law of this Colony, without repeal, forever.

XXIII. That every per≈øon, who ≈øhall be elected as afore≈øaid to be a member of the Legi≈ølative Council, or Hou≈øe of A≈ø≈øembly, ≈øhall, previous to his taking his ≈øeat in Council or A≈ø≈øembly, take the following oath or affirmation, viz.

"I, A. B. do ≈øolemnly declare, that, as a member of the Legi≈øl ‚Ä¢ tive Council [or A≈ø≈øembly, as the ca≈øe may be,] of the Colony of New-Jer≈øey, I will not a≈ø≈øent to any law, vote or proceeding, which ≈øhall appear to me injurious to the public welfare of ≈øaid Colony, nor that ≈øhall annul or repeal that part of the third ≈øection in the Charter of this Colony, which e≈øtabli≈øhes, that the elections of members of the Legi≈ølative Council and A≈ø≈øembly ≈øhall be annual; nor that part of the twenty-≈øecond ≈øection in ≈øaid Charter, re≈øpecting the trial by jury, nor that ≈øhall annul, repeal, or alter any part or parts of the eighteenth or nineteenth ≈øections of the ≈øame."
And any per≈øon or per≈øons, who ≈øhall be elected as afore≈øaid, is hereby empowered to admini≈øter to the ≈øaid members the ≈øaid oath or affirmation.

Provided always, and it is the true intent and meaning of this Congre≈øs, that if a reconciliation between Great-Britain and the≈øe Colonies ≈øhould take place, and the latter be taken again under the protection and government of the crown of Britain, this Charter ≈øhall be null and void‚Äîotherwi≈øe to remain firm and inviolable.

div.head: THE CONSTITUTION OF PENNSYLVANIA.
CONSTITUTION OF THE COMMONWEALTH OF PENNSYLVANIA, As ratified in Convention, the 2d Day of September, 1790.
div.p: WE the people of the Commonwealth of Penn≈øylvania, ordain and e≈øtabli≈øh this Con≈øtitution for its government.

div.head: ARTICLE I.
div.p: I. THE legi≈ølative power of this Commonwealth ≈øhall be ve≈øted in a General A≈ø≈øembly, which ≈øhall con≈øi≈øt of a Senate and Hou≈øe of Repre≈øentatives.
II. The Repre≈øentatives ≈øhall be cho≈øen annually, by the citizens of the city of Philadelphia, and of each county re≈øpectively, on the ≈øecond Tue≈øday of October.

III. No per≈øon ≈øhall be a Repre≈øentative who ≈øhall not have attained the age of twenty-one years, and have been a citizen and inhabitant of the State three years next preceding his election, and the la≈øt year thereof an inhabitant of the city or county, in which he ≈øhall be cho≈øen; unle≈øs he ≈øhall have been ab≈øent on the public bu≈øine≈øs of the United States, or of this State. No per≈øon, re≈øiding within any city, town, or borough, which ≈øhall be entitled to a ≈øeparate repre≈øentation, ≈øhall be elected a member for any county; nor ≈øhall any per≈øon, re≈øiding without the limits of any ≈øuch city, town, or borough, be elected a member therefor.

IV. Within three years after the fir≈øt meeting of the General A≈ø≈øembly, and within every ≈øub≈øequent term of ≈øeven years, an enumeration of the taxable inhabitants ≈øhall be made, in ≈øuch manner as ≈øhall be directed by law. The number of Repre≈øentatives ≈øhall, at the ≈øeveral periods of making ≈øuch enumeration, be fixed by the Legi≈ølature, and
apportioned among the city of Philadelphia, and the ≈øeveral counties, according to the number of taxable inhabitants in each; and ≈øhall never be le≈øs than ≈øixty, nor greater than one hundred. Each county ≈øhall have, at lea≈øt, one Repre≈øentative: but no county, hereafter erected, ≈øhall be entitled to a ≈øeparate repre≈øentation, until a ≈øufficient number of taxable inhabitants ≈øhall be contained within it, to entitle them to one Repre≈øentative, agreeable to the ratio which ≈øhall then be e≈øtabli≈øhed.

V. The Senators ≈øhall be cho≈øen for four years, by the citizens of Philadelphia, and of the ≈øeveral counties, at the ≈øame time, in the ≈øame manner, and at the ≈øame places where they ≈øhall vote for Repre≈øentatives.

VI. The number of Senators ≈øhall, at the ≈øeveral periods of making the enumeration before mentioned, be fixed by the Legi≈ølature, and apportioned among the di≈øtricts formed as herein after directed, according to the number of taxable inhabitants in each; and ≈øhall never be le≈øs than one fourth, nor greater than one third, of the number of Repre≈øentatives.

VII. The Senators ≈øhall be cho≈øen in di≈øtricts, to be formed by the Legi≈ølature; each di≈øtrict containing ≈øuch a number of taxable inhabitants, as ≈øhall be entitled to elect not more than four Senators. When a di≈øtrict ≈øhall be compo≈øed of two or more counties, they ≈øhall be adjoining. Neither the city of Philadelphia, nor any county, ≈øhall be divided, in forming a di≈øtrict.

VIII. No per≈øon ≈øhall be a Senator who ≈øhall not have attained the age of twenty-five years, and have been a citizen and inhabitant of the State four years next before his election, and the la≈øt year thereof an inhabitant of the di≈øtrict for which he ≈øhall be cho≈øen; unle≈øs he ≈øhall have been ab≈øent on the public bu≈øine≈øs of the United States, or of this State.

IX. Immediately after the Senators ≈øhall be a≈ø≈øembled, in con≈øequence of the fir≈øt election, ≈øub≈øequent to the fir≈øt enumeration, they ≈øhall be divided, by lot, as equally as may be, into four cla≈ø≈øes. div.head: A. DECLARATION OF RIGHTS and Fundamental Rules of the DELAWARE STATE, formerly ≈øtyled, The Government of the Counties of Newca≈øtle, Kent, and Su≈ø≈øex upon Delaware.
div.p: I. THAT all government of right originates from the people, is founded in compact only, and in≈øtituted ≈øolely for the good of the whole.

II. That all men have a natural and unalienable right to wor≈øhip Almighty God according to the dictates of their own con≈øciences and under≈øtanding ‚Ä¢ ; and that no man ought, or of right can be compelled to attend any religious wor≈øhip, or maintain any mini≈øtry, contrary to, or again≈øt his own free will-and con≈øent; and that-no authority can or ought to be ve≈øted in, or a≈ø≈øumed by, any power whatever, that ≈øhall in any ca≈øe interfere with, or in any manner control the right of con≈øcience, in the free exerci≈øe of religious wor≈øhip.

III. That all per≈øons, profe≈ø≈øing the Chri≈øtian religion, ought forever to enjoy equal rights and privileges, in this S ‚Ä¢ ate; unle≈øs, under colour of religion, any man di≈øturb the peace, the happine≈øs, or ≈øafety of ≈øociety.
IV. That the people of this State have the ≈øole, exclu≈øive, and inherent right of governing and regulating the internal police of the ≈øame.

V. That per≈øons intru≈øted with the legi≈ølative and executive powers, are the tru≈øtees and ≈øervants of the public, and, as ≈øuch, accountable for their conduct; wheref ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ , whenever the ends of government are perverted, and p ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ i ‚Ä¢ liberty manife≈øtly endangered, by the legi≈ølative ≈øing ‚Ä¢ y, or a treacherous combination of both, the people may,
and of right ought to e≈øtabli≈øh a new or reform the old government.

VI. That the right, in the people, to participate in the Legi≈ølature, is the foundation of liberty and of all free government; and for this end, all elections ought to be free and frequent: and every freeman, having ≈øufficient evidence of a permanent common intere≈øt with, and attachment to the community, hath a right of ≈øuffrage.
VII. That no power of ≈øu≈øpending laws, or the execution of laws, ought to be exerci≈øed, unle≈øs by the Legi≈ølature.
VIII. That, for redre≈øs of grievances, and for amending and ≈øtrengthening of the laws, the Legi≈ølature ought to be frequently convened.
IX. That every man hath a right to petition the Legi≈ølature for the redre≈øs of grievances, in a peaceable and orderly manner.

X. That every member of ≈øociety hath a right to be protected, in the enjoyment of life, liberty, and property, and therefore is bound to contribute his proportion towards the expen≈øe of that protection, and yield his per≈øonal ≈øervice, when nece≈ø≈øary, or an equivalent thereto; but no part of a man's property can be ju≈øtly taken from him, or applied to public u≈øes, without his own con≈øent, or that of his legal Repre≈øentatives: nor can any man, that is con≈øcientiou≈øly ≈øcrupulous of bearing arms in any ca≈øe, be ju≈øtly compelled thereto, if he will pay ≈øuch equivalent.
XI. That retro≈øpective laws, puni≈øhing offences committed before the exi≈øtence of ≈øuch laws, are oppre≈ø≈øive and unju≈øt, and ought not to be made.

XII. That every freeman, for every injury done him in his goods, lands, or per≈øon, by any other per≈øon, ought to have remedy, by the cour≈øe of the law of the land, and ought to have ju≈øtice and right for the injury done to him, freely without ≈øale, fully without any denial, and ≈øpeedily without delay, according to the law of the land.
XIII. That trial, by jury, of facts where they ari≈øe, is one of the greate≈øt ≈øecurities of the lives, liberties, and e≈øtates of the people.

XIV. That in all pro≈øecutions for criminal offences, every man hath a right to be informed of the accu≈øation again≈øt
him, to be allowed coun≈øel, to be confronted with the accu≈øers or witne≈ø≈øes, to examine evidence on oath in his favour, and to a ≈øpeedy trial, by an impartial jury, without who≈øe unanimous con≈øent he ought not to be found guilty.
XV. That no man, in the courts of common law, ought to be compelled to give evidence again≈øt him≈øelf.
XVI. That exce≈ø≈øive bail ought not to be required, nor exce≈ø≈øive ≈øines impo≈øed, nor cruel nor unu≈øual puni≈øhments inflicted.

XVII. That all warrants, without oath, to ≈øearch ≈øu≈øpected places, or to ≈øeize any per≈øon or his property, are grievous and oppre≈ø≈øive; and all general warrants‚Äîto ≈øearch ≈øu≈øpected places, or to apprehend all per≈øons ≈øu≈øpected, without naming or de≈øcribing the place or any per≈øon in ≈øpecial‚Äîare illegal, and ought not to be granted.
XVIII. That a well-regulated militia is the proper, natural, and ≈øafe defence of a free government.
XIX. That ≈øtanding armies are dangerous to liberty, and ought not to be rai≈øed or kept up, without the con≈øent of the Legi≈ølature.
XX. That, in all ca≈øes, and at all times, the military ought to be under ≈øtrict ≈øubordination to, and governed by, the civil power.
XXI. That no ≈øoldier ought to be quartered in any hou≈øe, in time of peace, without the con≈øent of the owner; and in time of war, in ≈øuch manner only, as the Legi≈ølature ≈øhall direct.
XXII. That the independency and uprightne≈øs of Judges are e≈ø≈øential to the impartial admini≈øtration of ju≈øtice, and a great ≈øecurity to the rights and liberties of the people.
XXIII. That the liberty of the pre≈øs ought to be inviolably pre≈øerved.

div.head: The CONSTITUTION, or SYSTEM of GOVERNMENT, agreed to and re≈øolved upon by the Repre≈øentatives, in full Convention, of the DELAWARE STATE, formerly ≈øtyled, The Government of the Counties of Newca≈øtle, Kent, and Su≈ø≈øex, upon Delaware; the ≈øaid Repre≈øentatives being cho≈øen by the freemen of the ≈øaid State, for that expre≈øs purpo≈øe.
div.p: I. THE government of the counties of Newca≈øtle, Kent, and Su≈ø≈øex, upon Delaware, ≈øhall hereafter, in all public and other writings, be called, The Delaware State.
II. The Legi≈ølature ≈øhall be formed of two di≈øtinct branches. They ≈øhall meet once or oftener in every year, and ≈øhall be called, The General A≈ø≈øembly of Delaware.

III. One of the branches of the Legi≈ølature ≈øhall be called, The Hou≈øe of A≈ø≈øembly, and ≈øhall con≈øi≈øt of ≈øeven Repre≈øentatives, to be cho≈øen for each county annually, of ≈øuch per≈øons as are freeholders of the ≈øame.

IV. The other branch ≈øhall be called, The Council, and con≈øi≈øt of nine members; three to be cho≈øen for each county at the time of the fir≈øt election of the A≈ø≈øembly, who ≈øhall be freeholders of the county for which they are cho≈øen, and be upwards of twenty five years of age. At the end of one year after the general election, the Coun≈øellor who had the ≈ømalle≈øt number of votes in each county ≈øhall be di≈øplaced, and the vacancies, thereby occa≈øioned, ≈øupplied by the freemen of each county choo≈øing the ≈øame or another per≈øon, at a new election, in manner afore≈øaid. At the end of two years after the fir≈øt general election, the Coun≈øellor who ≈øtood ≈øecond in number of votes in each county ≈øhall be di≈øplaced, and the vacancies, thereby occa≈øioned, ≈øupplied by a new election, in manner afore≈øaid. And at the end of three years from the fir≈øt general election, the Coun≈øellor who had the greate≈øt number of votes in each county ≈øhall be di≈øplaced, and the vacancies, thereby occa≈øioned, ≈øupplied by a new election in manner afore≈øaid. And this rotation, of a Coun≈øellor being di≈øplaced at the end of three years in each county, and his office ≈øupplied by a new choice, ≈øhall be continued afterwards in due order annually forever; whereby, after the fir≈øt general election,
a Coun≈øellor will remain in tru≈øt for three years from the time of his being elected, and a Coun≈øellor will be di≈øplaced; and the ≈øame or another cho≈øen in each county at every election.

V. The right of ≈øuffrage, in the election of members for both Hou≈øes, ≈øhall remain, as exerci≈øed by law at pre≈øent; and each Hou≈øe ≈øhall choo≈øe its own Speaker, appoint its own officers, judge of the qualifications and elections of its own members, ≈øettle its own rules of proceeding, and direct writs of election, for ≈øupplying intermediate vacancies. They may al≈øo ≈øeverally expel any of their own members for mi≈øbehaviour, but not a ≈øecond time in the ≈øame ≈øe≈ø≈øions for the ≈øame offence, if re-elected; and they ≈øhall have all other powers, nece≈ø≈øary for the Legi≈ølature of a free and independent State.

VI. All money bills, for the ≈øupport of government, ≈øhall originate in the Hou≈øe of A≈ø≈øembly, and may be altered, amended, or rejected, by the Legi≈ølative Council. All other bills and ordinances may take ri≈øe in the Hou≈øe of A≈ø≈øembly, or Legi≈ølative Council, and may be altered, amended, or rejected by either.

VII. A Pre≈øident or Chief Magi≈øtrate ≈øhall be cho≈øen by joint ballot of both Hou≈øes, to be taken in the Hou≈øe of A≈ø≈øembly, and the box examined by the Speakers of each Hou≈øe, in the pre≈øence of the other members; and in ca≈øe the numbers, for the two highe≈øt in votes, ≈øhould be equal, then the Speaker of the Council ≈øhall have an additional ca≈øting voice; and the appointment of the per≈øon, who has the majority of votes, ≈øhall be entered at large on the minutes and journals of each Hou≈øe; and a copy thereof, on parchment, certified and ≈øigned by the Speakers re≈øpectively, and ≈øealed with the Great Seal of the State, which they are hereby authori≈øed to affix, ≈øhall be delivered to the per≈øon ≈øo cho≈øen Pre≈øident, who ≈øhall continue in that office three years, and until the ≈øitting of the next General A≈ø≈øembly, and no longer; nor be eligible until the expiration of three years, after he ≈øhall have been out of that office. An adequate, but moderate ≈øalary ≈øhall be ≈øettled on him, during his continuance in office. He may draw for ≈øuch ≈øums of money, as ≈øhall be appropriated by the General A≈ø≈øembly, and be accountable to them for the
≈øame; he may, by and with the advice of the Privy Council, lay embargoes, or prohibit the exportation of any commodity, for any time not exceeding thirty days, in the rece≈øs of the General A≈ø≈øembly; he ≈øhall have the power of granting pardons or reprieves, except where the pro≈øecution ≈øhall be carried on by the Hou≈øe of A≈ø≈øembly, or the law ≈øhall otherwi≈øe direct; in which ca≈øes no pardon or reprieve ≈øhall be granted, but by a re≈øolve of the Hou≈øe of A≈ø≈øembly; and may exerci≈øe all the other executive powers of government, limited and re≈øtrained, as by this Con≈øtitution is mentioned, and according to the laws of the State. And on his death, inability, or ab≈øence from the State, the Speaker of the Legi≈ølative Council, for the time being, ≈øhall be Vice-Pre≈øident; and in ca≈øe of his death, inability, or ab≈øence from the State, the Speaker of the Hou≈øe of A≈ø≈øembly ≈øhall have the powers of a Pre≈øident, until a new nomination be made by the General A≈ø≈øembly.

VIII. A Privy Council, con≈øi≈øting of four members, ≈øhall be cho≈øen by ballot, two by the Legi≈ølative Council, and two by the Hou≈øe of A≈ø≈øembly: provided, that no regular officer of the army or navy, in the ≈øervice and pay of the Continent, or of this, or of any other State, ≈øhall be eligible. And a member of the Legi≈ølative Council, or of the Hou≈øe of A≈ø≈øembly, being cho≈øen of the Privy Council, and accepting thereof, ≈øhall thereby lo≈øe his ≈øeat. Three members ≈øhall be a quorum; and their advice and proceedings ≈øhall be entered on record, and ≈øigned by the members pre≈øent, (to any part of which, any member may enter his di≈ø≈øent) to be laid before the General A≈ø≈øembly when called for by them. Two members ≈øhall be removed by ballot, one by the Legi≈ølative Council, and one by the Hou≈øe of A≈ø≈øembly, at the end of two years; and tho≈øe who remain, the next year after; who ≈øhall ≈øeverally be ineligible for the three next years. The≈øe vacancies, as well as tho≈øe oc ‚Ä¢ a≈øioned by death or incapacity, ≈øhall be ≈øupplied by new elections, in the ≈øame manner. And this rotation of a Privy Coun≈øellor ≈øhall be continued afterwards in due order, annually, forever. The Pre≈øident may, by ≈øummons, convene the Privy Council, at any time when the public exigencies may require, and at ≈øuch place as he ≈øhall think mo≈øt convenient, when and where they are to attend accordingly.

div.head: The CONSTITUTION, or FORM of GOVERNMENT, &c.
div.p: WHEREAS allegiance and protection are, in their nature, reciprocal, and the one ≈øhould of right be refu≈øed when the other is withdrawn:

And whereas George the Third, King of Great Britain, and late Sovereign of the Briti≈øh American Colonies, hath-not only withdrawn from them his profection, but, by an act of the Briti≈øh Legi≈ølature, declared the inhabitants of the≈øe States out of the protection of the Briti≈øh crown, and all their property, found upon the high ≈øeas, liable to be ≈øeized and confi≈øcated to the u≈øes mentioned in the ≈øaid act; and the ≈øaid George the Third has al≈øo ≈øent fleets and armies to pro≈øecute a cruel war again≈øt them, for the purpo≈øe of reducing the inhabitants of the ≈øaid Colonies to a ≈øtate of abject ≈ølavery; in con≈øequence whereof, all government under the ≈øaid King, within the ≈øaid Colonies, hath cea≈øed, and a total di≈ø≈øolution of government in many of them hath taken place.

Provided, that after two thirds ≈øhall have concurred to proceed to alterations and amendments, a majority ≈øhall determine on the particulars of ≈øuch alterations and amendments.We have heard that a Convention was held, but have not heard of any alterations in this Con≈øtitution.

VIII. This Con≈øtitution ≈øhall take effect, and be in full force, on the fir≈øt Monday in October next, after the adoption of the ≈øame; and the executive ≈øhall be authori≈øed to alter the time for the ≈øitting of the Superior Courts, ≈øo that the ≈øame may not interfere with the annual elections in the re≈øpective counties, or the meeting of the fir≈øt General A≈ø≈øembly.

div.head: THE CONSTITUTION OF VERMONT.
div.p: WHEREAS all government ought to be in≈øtituted and ≈øupported for the ≈øecurity and protection of the community as ≈øuch, and to enable the individuals, who compo≈øe it, to enjoy their natural rights, and the other ble≈ø≈øings which the Author of exi≈øtence has be≈øtowed upon man: and whenever tho≈øe great ends of government are not obtained, the people have a right, by common con≈øent, to change it, and take ≈øuch mea≈øures as to them may appear nece≈ø≈øary, to promote their ≈øafety and happine≈øs.

And whereas the inhabitants of this State have (in con≈øideration of protection only) heretofore acknowledged allegiance to the King of Great-Britain: and the ≈øaid King has not only withdrawn that protection, but commenced and ≈øtill continues to carry on, with unabated vengeance, a mo≈øt cruel and unju≈øt war again≈øt them; employing therein not only the troops of Great-Britain, but foreign mercenaries, ≈øavages, and ≈ølaves, for the avowed purpo≈øe of reducing them to a total and abject ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion to the de≈øpotic domination of the Briti≈øh Parliament, with many more acts of tyranny, (more fully ≈øet forth in the Declaration of Congre≈øs) whereby all allegiance and fealty to the ≈øaid King and his Succe≈ø≈øors, are di≈ø≈øolved and at an end; and all power and authority derived from him cea≈øed in the American Colonies. And whereas the Territory, which now comprehends the State of Vermont, did antecedently of right belong to the government of New-Hamp≈øhire, and the former Governor thereof, viz. his excellency Benning Wentworth, E≈øq granted many charters of lands and corporations within this State to the pre≈øent inhabitants and others. And whereas the late Lieutenant-Governor Colden, of New York, with others, did, in violation of the tenth command, covet tho≈øe very lands: and by a fal≈øe
repre≈øentation, made to the Court of Great-Britain, (in the year 1764, that for the convenience of trade and admini≈øtration of ju≈øtice, the inhabitants were de≈øirous of being annexed to that government) obtained juri≈ødiction of tho≈øe very identical lands, ex parte, which ever was and is di≈øagreeable to the inhabitants. And whereas the Legi≈ølature of New-York ever have, and ≈øtill continue to di≈øown the good people of this State, in their landed property, which will appear in the complaints hereafter in≈øerted, and in the 36th ≈øection of their pre≈øent Con≈øtitution, in which is e≈øtabli≈øhed the Grants of Land made by that government.

They have refu≈øed to make re-grants of our lands to the original Proprietors and Occupants, unle≈øs at the exorbitant rate of 2,300 dollars fees for each town≈øhip; and did enhance the quitrent three-fold, and demanded an immediate delivery of the title derived from New-Hamp≈øhire.

The Judges of their Supreme Court have made a ≈øolemn declaration, that the charters, conveyances, &c. of the lands included in the before-de≈øcribed premi≈øes, were utterly null and void, on which ≈øaid title was founded. In con≈øequence of which declaration, writs of po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion have been by them i≈ø≈øued, and the Sheriff of the county of Albany ≈øent at the head of ≈øix or ≈øeven hundred men, to enforce the execution thereof.

They have pa≈ø≈øed an act, annexing a penalty thereto, of thirty pounds' fine, and ≈øix months' impri≈øonment, on any per≈øon who ≈øhould refu≈øe a≈ø≈øi≈øting the Sheriff, after being reque≈øted, for the purpo≈øe of executing writs of po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion.

The Governors Dunmore, Tryon, and Colden, have made re-grants of ≈øeveral tracts of land included in the premi≈øes, to certain favourite land jobbers in the government of New-York, in direct violation of his Britannic Maje≈øty's expre≈øs prohibition, in the year 1767.

They have i≈ø≈øued proclamations, wherein they have offered large ≈øums of money for the purpo≈øe of apprehending tho≈øe very per≈øons, who have dared boldly and publickly to appear in defence of their ju≈øt rights.

They did pa≈øs twelve acts of outlawry on the ninth day of March, A. D. 1774, empowering the re≈øpective Judges of their Supreme Court to award execution of death again≈øt tho≈øe inhabitants in ≈øaid di≈øtrict, that they ≈øhould judge to be offenders, without trial.
They have and ≈øtill continue an unju≈øt claim to tho≈øe lands, which greatly retards emigration into any ≈øettlement of this State.
They have hired foreign troops, emigrants from Scotland, at two different times, and armed them to drive us out of po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion.
They have ≈øent the Savages on our frontiers to di≈øtre≈øs us.
They have proceeded to erect the counties of Cumberland and Glouce≈øter, and e≈øtabli≈øh courts of ju≈øtice there, after they were di≈øcountenanced by the authority of Great-Britain.

The free Convention of the State of New-York, at Harlem, in the year 1776, unanimou≈øly voted, "That all quitrents, formerly due to the King of Great-Britain, are now due, and owing to this Convention, or ≈øuch future government as ≈øhall be hereafter e≈øtabli≈øhed in this State."

In the ≈øeveral ≈øtages of the afore≈øaid oppre≈ø≈øions, we have petitioned his Britannic Maje≈øty in the mo≈øt humble manner for redre≈øs, and have, at very great expen≈øe, received ≈øeveral reports in our favour: and in other in≈øtances, wherein we have petitioned the late legi≈ølative authority of New-York, tho≈øe petitions have been treated with neglect. And whereas, the local ≈øituation of this State from New-York, which, at the extreme part, is upward of four hundred and fifty miles from the ≈øeat of that government, renders it extreme difficult to continue under the juri≈ødiction of ≈øaid State;

Therefore it is ab≈øolutely nece≈ø≈øary, for the welfare and ≈øafety of the inhabitants of this State, that it ≈øhould be henceforth a free and independent State, and that a ju≈øt, permanent, and proper form of government ≈øhould exi≈øt in it, derived from and founded on the authority of the people only, agreeable to the direction of the honourable American Congre≈øs.

We the Repre≈øentatives of the freemen of Vermont, in General Convention met, for the expre≈øs purpo≈øe of forming ≈øuch a government‚Äîconfe≈ø≈øing the goodne≈øs of the great Governor of the univer≈øe (who alone knows to what degree of earthly happine≈øs mankind may attain by perfecting the arts of government) in permitting the people
of this State, by common con≈øent, and without violence, deliberately to form for them≈øelves ≈øuch ju≈øt rules as they ≈øhall think be≈øt, for governing their future ≈øociety; and being fully convinced, that it is o ‚Ä¢ r indi≈øpen≈øable duty to e≈øtabli≈øh ≈øuch original principles of government as will be≈øt promote the general happine≈øs of the people of this State, and their po≈øterity, and provide for future improvements, without partiality for, or prejudice again≈øt, any particular cla≈øs, ≈øect, or denomination of men whatever; do, by virtue of authority ve≈øted in us by our con≈øtituents, ordain, declare and e≈øtabli≈øh the following Declaration of Rights, and Frame of Government, to be the Con≈øtitution of this Commonwealth, and to remain in force therein forever unaltered, except in ≈øuch articles as ≈øhall hereafter on experience be found to require improvement, and which ≈øhall, by the ≈øame authority of the people, fairly delegated, as this Frame of Government directs, be amended or improved, for the more effectual obtaining and ≈øecuring the great end and de≈øign of all government, herein before mentioned.

div.head: CHAPTER I. A DECLARATION of the RIGHTS of the INHABITANTS of the STATE of VERMONT.
div.p: I. THAT all men are born equally free and independent, and have certain natural, inherent and unalienable rights; among≈øt which are, the enjoying and defending life and liberty‚Äîacquiring, po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øing and protecting property‚Äîand pur≈øuing and obtaining happine≈øs and ≈øafety. Therefore, no male per≈øon, born in this country, or brought from over ≈øea, ought to be holden by law to ≈øerve any per≈øon, as a ≈øervant, ≈ølave, or apprentice, after he arrives to the age of twenty-one years; nor female, in like manner, after ≈øhe arrives to the age of eighteen years; unle≈øs they are bound by their own con≈øent after they arrive to ≈øuch age; or bound by law for the payment of debts, damages, fines, co≈øts, or the like.

II. That private property ought to be ≈øub≈øervient to public u≈øes, when nece≈ø≈øity requires it; neverthele≈øs, whenever
any particular man's property is taken for the u≈øe of the public, the owner ought to receive an equivalent in money.

III. That all men have a natural and unalienable right to wor≈øhip Almighty God according to the dictates of their own con≈øciences and under≈øtandings, as in their opinion ≈øhall be regulated by the word of God; and that no man ought, or of right can be compelled to attend any religious wor≈øhip, or erect or ≈øupport any place of wor≈øhip, or maintain any mini≈øter, contrary to the dictates of his con≈øcience; nor can any man be ju≈øtly deprived or abridged of any civil right as a citizen, on account of his religious ≈øentiments, or peculiar mode of religious wor≈øhip; and that no authority can, or ought to be ve≈øted in, or a≈ø≈øumed by any power what≈øoever, that ≈øhall in any ca≈øe interfere with, or in any manner control the rights of con≈øcience, in the free exerci≈øe of religious wor≈øhip: Neverthele≈øs, every ≈øect or denomination of Chri≈øtians ought to ob≈øerve the Sabbath or Lord's day, and keep up ≈øome ≈øort of religious wor≈øhip, which to them ≈øhall ≈øeem mo≈øt agreeable to the revealed will of God.

IV. Every per≈øon within this Commonwealth ought to find a certain remedy, by having recour≈øe to the laws, for all injuries or wrongs which he may receive in his per≈øon, property, or character: he ought to obtain right and ju≈øtice freely, and without being obliged to purcha≈øe it‚Äîcompletely, and without any denial‚Äîpromptly, and without delay; conformably to the laws.
V. That the people of this State, by their legal repre≈øentatives, have the ≈øole, exclu≈øive and inherent right of governing and regulating the internal police of the ≈øame.

VI. That all power being originally inherent in, and con≈øequently derived from the people; therefore, all officers of government, whether legi≈ølative or executive, are their tru≈øtees and ≈øervants, and at all times, in a legal way, accountable to them.

VII. That government is, or ought to be, in≈øtituted for the common benefit, protection and ≈øecurity of the people, nation, or community, and not for the particular emolument or advantage of any ≈øingle man, family, or ≈øet of men, who are a part only of that community: and that the community hath an indubitable, unalienable, and indefea≈øible right, to reform or alter government, in ≈øuch manner as ≈øhall be,
by that community, judged to be mo≈øt conducive to the public weal.

VIII. That tho≈øe who are employed in the legi≈ølative and executive bu≈øine≈øs of the State may be re≈øtrained from oppre≈ø≈øion, the people have a right, by their legal repre≈øentatives, to enact laws for reducing their public officers to a private ≈øtation, and for ≈øupplying their vacancies in a con≈øtitutional manner, by regular elections, at ≈øuch periods as they may think proper.

IX. That all elections ought to be free and without corruption; and that all freemen, having a ≈øufficient evident common intere≈øt with, and attachment to the community, have a right to elect officers, and be elected into office.

X. That every member of ≈øociety hath a right to be protected in the enjoyment of life, liberty and property; and therefore is bound to contribute his proportion towards the expen≈øe of that protection, and yield his per≈øonal ≈øervice, when nece≈ø≈øary, or an equivalent thereto: but no part of a man's property can be ju≈øtly taken from him, or applied to public u≈øes, without his own con≈øent, or that of the repre≈øentative body of the freemen; nor can any man, who is con≈øcientiou≈øly ≈øcrupulous of bearing arms, be ju≈øtly compelled thereto, if he will pay ≈øuch equivalent; nor are the people bound by any law, but ≈øuch as they have in like manner a≈ø≈øented to, for their common good. And previous to any law being made to rai≈øe a tax, the purpo≈øe, for which it is to be rai≈øed ought to appear evident to the Legi≈ølature to be of more ≈øervice to the community, than the money would be if not collected.

XI. That in all pro≈øecutions for criminal offences, a man hath a right to be heard by him≈øelf and his coun≈øel‚Äî to demand the cau≈øe and nature of his accu≈øation‚Äîto be confronted with the witne≈ø≈øes‚Äîto call for evidence in his favour, and a ≈øpeedy public trial by an impartial jury of the country, without the unanimous con≈øent of which jury he cannot be found guilty‚Äînor can he be compelled to give evidence again≈øt him≈øelf‚Äînor can any man be ju≈øtly deprived of his liberty, except by the laws of the land, or the judgment of his peers.

XII. That the people have a right to hold them≈øelves, their hou≈øes, papers and po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions, free from ≈øearch or ≈øeizure: and therefore warrants, without oaths or affirmations
fir≈øt made, affording ≈øufficient foundation for them, and whereby any officer or me≈ø≈øenger may be commanded or required to ≈øearch ≈øu≈øpected places, or to ≈øeize any per≈øon or per≈øons, his, her or their property not particularly de≈øcribed, are contrary to that right, and ought not to be granted.

XIII. That no warrant or writ to attach the per≈øon or e≈øtate of any freeholder within this State, ≈øhall be i≈ø≈øued in civil action, without the per≈øon or per≈øons, who may reque≈øt ≈øuch warrant or attachment, fir≈øt make oath, or affirm before the authority who may be reque≈øted to i≈ø≈øue the ≈øame, that he or they are in danger of lo≈øing his, her, or their debts.
XIV. That when an i≈ø≈øue in fact, proper for the cognizance of a jury, is joined in a court of law, the parties have a right to a trial by jury; which ought to be held ≈øacred.

XV. That the people have a right of fredom of ≈øpeech and of writing and publi≈øhing their ≈øentiments, concerning the tran≈øactions of government‚Äîand therefore the freedom of the pre≈øs ought not to be re≈øtrained.

XVI. The freedom of deliberation, ≈øpeech, and debate, in the legi≈ølature, is ≈øo e≈ø≈øential to the rights of the people, that it cannot be the foundation of any accu≈øation or pro≈øecution, action or complaint, in any other court or place what≈øoever.

XVII. The power of ≈øu≈øpending laws, or the execution of laws, ought never to be exerci≈øed, but by the Legi≈ølature, or by authority derived from it, to be exerci≈øed in ≈øuch particular ca≈øes only as the Legi≈ølature ≈øhall expre≈øsly provide for.

XVIII. That the people have a right to bear arms, for the defence of them≈øelves and the State: and as ≈øtanding armies, in the time of peace, are dangerous to liberty, they ought not to be kept up; and that the military ≈øhould be kept under ≈øtrict ≈øubordination to, and governed by the civil power.

XIX. That no per≈øon in this Commonwealth can, in any ca≈øe, be ≈øubjected to law-martial or to any penalties or pains, by virtue of that law, except tho≈øe employed in the army, and the militia in actual ≈øervice.

XX. That frequent recurrence to fundamental principles, and a firm adherence to ju≈øtice, moderation, temperance, indu≈øtry, and frugality, are ab≈øolutely nece≈ø≈øary to pre≈øerve the ble≈ø≈øings of liberty, and keep government free; the people ought therefore to pay particular attention to the≈øe points, in the choice of officers and repre≈øentatives; and have a right, in a legal way, to exact a due and con≈øtant regard to them, from their legi≈ølators and magi≈øtrates, in the making and executing ≈øuch laws as are nece≈ø≈øary for the good government of the State.

XXI. That all people have a natural and inherent right to emigrate from one State to another, that will receive them; or to form a new State in vacant countries, or in ≈øuch countries as they can purcha≈øe, whenever they think that thereby they can promote their own happine≈øs.

XXII. That the people have a right to a≈ø≈øemble together, to con≈øult for their common good‚Äîto in≈øtruct their repre≈øentatives, and to apply to the Legi≈ølature for redre≈øs of grievances, by addre≈øs, petition or remon≈øtrance.
XXIII. That no per≈øon ≈øhall be liable to be tran≈øported out of this State, for trial for any offence committed within the ≈øame.

div.head: CHAP. II. PLAN or FRAME of GOVERNMENT.
div.p: SECT. I. THE Commonwealth or State of Vermont, ≈øhall be governed hereafter by a Governor, (or Lieutenant-Governor) Council, and an A≈ø≈øembly of the Repre≈øentatives of the freemen of the ≈øame, in manner and form following:
II. The ≈øupreme legi≈ølative power ≈øhall be ve≈øted in a Hou≈øe of Repre≈øentatives of the freemen, or Commonwealth, or State of Vermont.
III. The ≈øupreme executive power ≈øhall be ve≈øted in a Governor, (or, in his ab≈øence, a Lieutenant-Governor) and Council.

IV. Courts of ju≈øtice ≈øhall be maintained in every county in this State, and al≈øo in new counties when formed;
which courts ≈øhall be open for the trial of all cau≈øes proper for their cognizance, and ju≈øtice ≈øhall be therein impartially admini≈øtered, without corruption, or unnece≈ø≈øary delay. The Judges of the Supreme Court ≈øhall be Ju≈øtices of the Peace throughout the State; and the ≈øeveral Judges of the County Courts, in their re≈øpective counties, by virtue of their offices, except in the trial of ≈øuch cau≈øes as may be appealed to the County Court.

V. A future Legi≈ølature may, when they ≈øhall conceive the ≈øame to be expedient and nece≈ø≈øary, erect a Court of Chancery, with ≈øuch powers as are u≈øually exerci≈øed by that Court, or as ≈øhall appear for the intere≈øt of the Commonwealth: Provided they do not con≈øtitute them≈øelves the Judges of the ≈øaid Court.
VI. The legi≈ølative, executive and judiciary departments ≈øhall be ≈øeparate and di≈øtinct, ≈øo that neither exerci≈øe the powers properly belonging to the other.

VII. In order that the freemen of this State may enjoy the benefit of election, as equally as may be, each town within this State, that con≈øi≈øts or may con≈øi≈øt of eighty taxable inhabitants, within one ≈øeptenary or ≈øeven years next after the e≈øtabli≈øhing this Con≈øtitution, may hold elections therein, and choo≈øe each two repre≈øentatives; and each other inhabited town in this State may, in like manner, choo≈øe each one repre≈øentative to repre≈øent them in General A≈ø≈øembly, during the ≈øaid ≈øeptenary or ≈øeven years; and after that, each inhabited town may, in like manner, hold ≈øuch election, and choo≈øe each one repre≈øentative forever thereafter.

VIII. The Hou≈øe of Repre≈øentatives of the freemen of this State ≈øhall con≈øi≈øt of per≈øons mo≈øt noted for wi≈ødom and virtue, to be cho≈øen by ballot by the freemen of every town in this State re≈øpectively, on the fir≈øt Tue≈øday of September annually forever.

IX. The repre≈øentatives, ≈øo cho≈øen, (a majority of whom ≈øhall con≈øtitute a quorum for tran≈øacting any other bu≈øine≈øs than rai≈øing a State tax, for which two thirds of the members elected ≈øhall be pre≈øent) ≈øhall meet on the ≈øecond Thur≈øday of the ≈øucceeding October, and ≈øhall be ≈øtyled, The General A≈ø≈øembly of the State of Vermont: they ≈øhall have power to ‚Ä¢ ho≈øe ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ r Sp ‚Ä¢ aker, Secretary of the State,
their Clerk and other nece≈ø≈øary officers of the Hou≈øe‚Äî≈øit on their own adjournments‚Äîprepare bills, and enact them into laws‚Äîjudge of the elections and qualifications of their own members: they may expel members, but not for cau≈øes known to their con≈øtituents antecedent to their election; they may admini≈øter oaths, or affirmations, in matters depending before them‚Äîredre≈øs grievances‚Äîimpeach State criminals‚Äîgrant charters of incorporation‚Äîcon≈øtitute towns, boroughs, cities and counties: they may annually, in their fir≈øt ≈øe≈ø≈øion after their election, and at other times when vacancies happen, choo≈øe Delegates to Congre≈øs: and ≈øhall al≈øo, in conjunction with the Council, annually, (or oftener if need be) elect Judges of the Supreme and ≈øeveral County and Probate Courts, Sheriffs and Ju≈øtices of the Peace: and al≈øo with the Council, may elect Major-Generals and Brigadier-Generals, from time to time, as often as there ≈øhall be occa≈øion; and they ≈øhall have all other powers nece≈ø≈øary for the Legi≈ølature of a free and ≈øovereign State: but they ≈øhall have no power to add to, alter, aboli≈øh, or infringe, any part of this Con≈øtitution.

X. The Supreme Executive Council of this State ≈øhall con≈øi≈øt of a Governor, Lieutenant-Governor, and twelve per≈øons, cho≈øen in the following manner, viz. The freemen of each town ≈øhall, on the day of election for choo≈øing repre≈øentatives to attend the General A≈ø≈øembly, bring in their votes for Governor, with his name fairly written, to the Con≈øtable, who ≈øhall ≈øeal them up, and write on them, Votes for the Governor, and deliver them to the repre≈øentative cho≈øen to attend the General A≈ø≈øembly: and at the opening of the General A≈ø≈øembly, there ≈øhall be a committee appointed out of the Council and A≈ø≈øembly, who, after being duly ≈øworn to the faithful di≈øcharge of their tru≈øt, ≈øhall proceed to receive, ≈øort and count the votes for the Governor, and declare the per≈øon who has the major part of the votes to be Governor, for the year en≈øuing. And if there be no choice made, then the Council and General A≈ø≈øembly, by their joint ballot, ≈øhall make choice of a Governor.

The Lieutenant-Governor and Trea≈øurer ≈øhall be cho≈øen in the manner above directed. And each freeman ≈øhall give in twelve votes for twelve Coun≈øellors, in the ≈øame
manner: and the twelve highe≈øt in nomination ≈øhall ≈øerve for the en≈øuing year as coun≈øellors.

XI. The Governor, and in his ab≈øence, the Lieutenant-Governor, with the Council, (a major part of whom, including the Governor or Lieutenant-Governor, ≈øhall be a quorum to tran≈øact bu≈øine≈øs) ≈øhall have power to commi≈ø≈øionate all officers‚Äîand al≈øo to appoint officers, except where provi≈øion is or ≈øhall be otherwi≈øe made by law, or this frame of government; and ≈øhall ≈øupply every vacancy in any office occa≈øioned by death or otherwi≈øe, until the office can be filled in the manner directed by law or this Con≈øtitution. XVI. That exce≈ø≈øive bail ≈øhall not be required, nor exce≈ø≈øive fines impo≈øed, nor cruel and unu≈øual puni≈øhments inflicted.

XVII. That all courts ≈øhall be open: and every man, for an injury done him in his lands, goods, per≈øon, or reputation, ≈øhall have remedy by due cour≈øe of law, and right and ju≈øtice admini≈øtered without ≈øale, denial, or delay. Suits may be brought again≈øt the ≈øtate in ≈øuch manner and in ≈øuch courts as the Legi≈ølature may by law direct, provided the right of bringing ≈øuit be limited to the citizens of this ≈øtate.

XVIII. That the per≈øon of a debtor, where there is not ≈øtrong pre≈øumption of frand, ≈øhall not be continued in pri≈øon, after delivering up his e≈øtate for the benefit of his creditor or creditors, in ≈øuch manner as ≈øhall be pre≈øcribed by law.

XIX. That the printing pre≈ø≈øes ≈øhall be free to every per≈øon who undertakes to examine the proceedings of the Legi≈ølature, or of any branch or officer of government; and no law ≈øhall ever be made to re≈øtrain the right thereof. The free communication of thoughts and opinions, is one of the invaluable rights of man; and every citizen may
freely ≈øpeak, write, and print on any ≈øubject, being re≈øpon≈øible for the abu≈øe of that liberty. But in pro≈øecutions for the publication of papers inve≈øtigating the official conduct of officers or men in public capacity, the truth thereof may be given in evidence; and in all indictments for libels, the jury ≈øhall have a right to determine the law and the facts, under the direction of the court, as in other ca≈øes.
XX. That no retro≈øpective law, or law impairing the obligation of contracts, ≈øhall be made.

XXI. That no man's particular ≈øervices ≈øhall be demanded, or property taken, or applied to public u≈øe, without the con≈øent of his repre≈øentatives, or without ju≈øt compen≈øation being-made therefor.

XXII. That the citizens have a right, in a peaceable manner, to a≈ø≈øemble together for their common good, to in≈øtruct their repre≈øentatives, and to apply to tho≈øe inve≈øted with the powers of government for redre≈øs of grievances, or other proper purpo≈øes, by addre≈øs or remon≈øtrance.
XXIII. That perpetuities and monopolies are contrary to the genius of a free ≈øtate, and ≈øhall not be allowed.

XXIV. That the ≈øure and certain defence of a free people is a well regulated militia; and as ≈øtanding armies, in time of peace, are dangerous to freedom, they ought to be avoided, as far as the circum≈øtances and ≈øafety of the community will admit; and that in all ca≈øes the military ≈øhall be in ≈øtrict ≈øubordination to the civil authority.
XXV. That no citizen in this State, except ≈øuch as are employed in the army of the United States, or militia in actual ≈øervice, ≈øhall be ≈øubject to corporal puni≈øhment under the martial law.
XXVI. That the freemen of this State have a right to keep and to bear arms for their common defence.
XXVII. That no ≈øoldier ≈øhall, in time of peace, be quartered in any hou≈øe without con≈øent of the owner, nor in time of war but in a manner pre≈øcribed by law.
XXVIII. That no citizen of this State ≈øhall be compelled to bear arms, provided he will pay an equivalent, to be a≈øcertained by law.

XXIX. That an equal participation of the free navigation of the Mi≈ø≈øi≈øippi, is one of the inherent rights of
the citizens of this State: it cannot, therefore, be conceded to any prince, potentate, power, per≈øon, or per≈øons whatever.
XXX. That no hereditary emoluments, privileges, or honours ≈øhall ever be granted or conferred in this State.
XXXI. That the people re≈øiding ≈øouth of French Broad and Hol≈øton, between the rivers Tenne≈ø≈øee and the Big Pigeon, are entitled to the right of pre-emption and occupancy in that tract.

XXXII. That the limits and boundaries of this State be a≈øcertained, it is declared they are as hereafter mentioned; that is to ≈øay:‚ÄîBeginning on the extreme height of the Stone Mountain, at the place where the line of Virginia inter≈øects it, in latitude thirty ≈øix degrees and thirty minutes North‚Äîrunning thence along the extreme height of the ≈øaid Mountain, to the place where Watauga River breaks through it; thence a direct cour≈øe to the top of the Yellow Mountain, where Bright's road cro≈ø≈øes the ≈øame; thence along the ridge of ≈øaid Mountain, between the waters of Doe River and the waters of Rock Creek, to the place where the road cro≈ø≈øes the Iron Mountain; from thence along the extreme height of ≈øaid Mountain to where Nolichucky River runs through the ≈øame; thence to the top of the Bald Mountain; thence along the extreme height of ≈øaid Mountain to the painted Rock, on French Broad River; thence along the highe≈øt ridge of ≈øaid Mountain, to the place where it is called the Great Iron or Smoky Mountain; thence along the extreme height of ≈øaid Mountain to the place where it is called Unicoi or Unaka Mountain, between the Indian Towns of Cowee and Old Chota; thence along the main ridge of the ≈øaid Mountain to the ≈øouthern boundary of this State, as de≈øcribed in the act of ce≈ø≈øion of North-Carolina to the United States of America; and that all the Territory lands and waters lying We≈øt of the ≈øaid line, as before mentioned, and contained within the chartered limits of the State of North-Carolina, are within the boundaries and limits of this State, over which the people have the right of exerci≈øing ≈øovereignty and right of ≈øoil ≈øo far as is con≈øi≈øtent, with the con≈øtitution of the United States, recognizing the articles of confederation, the bill of rights
and con≈øtitution of North Carolina, the ce≈ø≈øion act of the ≈øaid State, and the ordinance of the late Congre≈øs, for the government of the Territory North-We≈øt of the Ohio; provided nothing herein contained ≈øhall extend to affect the claim or claims of individuals, to any part of the ≈øoil which is recognized to them by the afore≈øaid ce≈ø≈øion act.

div.head: SCHEDULE.
div.p: SEC. I. That no inconvenience may ari≈øe from a change of the temporary to a permanent State government, it is declared, that all rights, actions, pro≈øecutions, claims, and contracts, as well of individuals as of bodies corporate, ≈øhall continue, as if no change had taken place in the admini≈øtration of government.

SEC. II. All fines, penalties, and forfeitures, due and owing to the territory of the United States of America ≈øouth of the river Ohio, ≈øhall enure to the u≈øe of the State. div.head: THE CONSTITUTION OF KENTUCKEY.
div.p: WE, the Repre≈øentatives of the People of the State of Kentuckey, in Convention a≈ø≈øembled, do ordain and e≈øtabli≈øh this Con≈øtitution for its Government.

div.head: ARTICLE I.
div.p: The powers of government ≈øhall be divided into three di≈øtinct Departments, each of them to be con≈øided to a ≈øeparate body of Magi≈øtracy, to wit, tho≈øe which are Legi≈ølative to one, tho≈øe which are Executive to another, and tho≈øe which are Judiciary to another.

No per≈øon, or collection of per≈øons, being of one of the≈øe departments, ≈øhall exerci≈øe any power properly belonging to either of the others, except in the in≈øtances herein after expre≈øsly permitted.
The Legi≈ølative powers of this Commonwealth ≈øhall be ve≈øted in a General A≈ø≈øembly, which ≈øhall con≈øi≈øt of a Senate and Hou≈øe of Repre≈øentatives.

The Repre≈øentatives ≈øhall be cho≈øen annually, by the qualified electors of each county re≈øpectively, on the fir≈øt Tue≈øday in May; but the ≈øeveral elections may be continued for three days, if, in the opinion of the pre≈øiding officer or officers, it ≈øhall be nece≈ø≈øary, and no longer.

No per≈øon ≈øhall be a Repre≈øentative, who ≈øhall not have attained the age of twenty-four years, and have been a citizen and inhabitant of the ≈øtate two years preceding his election, and the la≈øt ≈øix mouths thereof an inhabitant of the county in which he may be cho≈øen; unle≈øs he ≈øhall have been ab≈øent on the public bu≈øine≈øs of the United States, or this ≈øtate.

Within two years after the fir≈øt meeting of the General A≈ø≈øembly, and within every ≈øub≈øequent term of four years,
an enumeration of the free male inhabitants above twenty-one years of age, ≈øhall be made in ≈øuch manner as may be directed by law. The number of the Repre≈øentatives ≈øhall, at the ≈øeveral periods of making ≈øuch enumeration, be fixed by the Legi≈ølature, and apportioned among the ≈øeveral counties, according to the number of free male inhabitants above the age of twenty-one years in each, and ≈øhall never be le≈øs than forty, nor greater than one hundred; but no county hereafter erected, ≈øhall be entitled to a ≈øeparate repre≈øentation, until a ≈øufficient number of free male inhabititants above the age of twenty-one years, ≈øhall be contained within it, to entitle them to one Repre≈øentative agreeable to the ratio which ≈øhall then be e≈øtabli≈øhed.

The Senators ≈øhall be cho≈øen for four years. Until the fir≈øt enumeration be made, the Senate ≈øhall con≈øi≈øt of eleven members, and thereafter for every four members added to the Hou≈øe of Repre≈øentatives, one member ≈øhall be added to the Senate.

In choo≈øing the Senate, one member at lea≈øt ≈øhall be elected from each county, until the number of counties is equal to the number of Senators: after which, when a new county is made, it ≈øhall, as to the choice of Senators, be con≈øidered as being a part of the county or counties from which it ≈øhall have been taken.

The Senate ≈øhall be cho≈øen in the following manner: All per≈øons qualified to vote for Repre≈øentatives, ≈øhall, on the fir≈øt Tue≈øday in May, in the pre≈øent year, and on the ≈øame day in every fourth year, forever thereafter, at the place appointed by law for choo≈øing Repre≈øentatives, elect by ballot, by a majority of votes, as many per≈øons as they are entitled to have for Repre≈øentatives for their re≈øpective counties, to be electors of the Senate.
No per≈øon ≈øhall be cho≈øen an elector, who ≈øhall not have re≈øided in the ≈øtate three years next before his election, and who ≈øhall not have attained the age of twenty-≈øeven years.

The electors of the Senate ≈øhall meet at ≈øuch place as ≈øhall be appointed for convening the Legi≈ølature, on the third Tue≈øday in May, in the pre≈øent year, and on the ≈øame day in every fourth year forever thereafter; and they, or a majority of them ≈øo met, ≈øhall proceed to elect by ballot,
as Senators, men of the mo≈øt wi≈ødom, experience and virtue, above twenty-≈øeven years of age, who ≈øhall have been re≈øidents of the ≈øtate above two whole years next preceding the election. If on the ballot two or more ≈øhall have an equal number of ballots in their favour, by which the choice ≈øhall not be determined by the fir≈øt ballot, then the electors ≈øhall again ballot before they ≈øeparate, in which they ≈øhall be confined to the per≈øons, who on the fir≈øt ballot ≈øhall have had an equal number, and they who ≈øhall have the greate≈øt number in their favour on the ≈øecond ballot, ≈øhall be accordingly declared and returned duly elected; and if on the ≈øecond ballot an equal number ≈øhall ≈øtill be in favour of two or more per≈øons, then the election ≈øhall be determined by lot, between tho≈øe who have equal numbers; which proceedings of the electors ≈øhall be certified under their hands, and returned to the Secretary for the time being; to whom ≈øhall al≈øo be made by the proper officers, returns of the per≈øons cho≈øen as electors in the re≈øpective counties.

The electors of Senators ≈øhall judge of the qualifications and elections of members of their body, and on a conte≈øted election, ≈øhall admit to a ≈øeat as an elector, ≈øuch qualified per≈øon as ≈øhall appear to them to have the greate≈øt number of legal votes in his favour.

The electors, immediately on their meeting, and before they proceed to the election of Senators, ≈øhall take an oath or affirmation, to elect, without favour, affection, partiality, or prejudice, ≈øuch per≈øon for Governor, and ≈øuch per≈øons for Senators, as they in their judgment and con≈øcience believe be≈øt qualified for the re≈øpective offices.

That in ca≈øe of refu≈øal, death, re≈øignation, di≈øqualification, or removal out of this ≈øtate, of any Senator, the Senate ≈øhall immediately thereupon, or at their next meeting thereafter, elect, by ballot, in the ≈øame manner as the electors are herein directed to choo≈øe Senators, another per≈øon in his place, for the re≈øidue of the ≈øaid term of four years.
The General A≈ø≈øembly ≈øhall meet on the fir≈øt Monday in November in every year, till the time of their meeting ≈øhall be altered by the Legi≈ølature, unle≈øs ≈øooner convened by the Governor.
Each Hou≈øe ≈øhall choo≈øe its Speaker and other officers, and the Senate ≈øhall al≈øo choo≈øe a Speaker, pro tempore, when their Speaker ≈øhall exerci≈øe the office of Governor.

Each Hou≈øe ≈øhall judge of the qualifications of its members: conte≈øted elections ≈øhall be determined by a committee to be ≈øelected, formed and regulated, in ≈øuch manner as ≈øhall be directed by law. A majority of each Hou≈øe ≈øhall con≈øtitute a quorum to do bu≈øine≈øs, but a ≈ømaller number may adjourn from day to day, and may be authori≈øed by law to compel the attendance of ab≈øent members, in ≈øuch manner and under ≈øuch penalties as may be provided.

Each Hou≈øe may determine the rules of its proceedings, puni≈øh its members for di≈øorderly behaviour, and with the concurrence of two thirds, expel a member; but not a ≈øecond time for the ≈øame cau≈øe.

Each Hou≈øe ≈øhall keep a journal of its proceedings, and publi≈øh them weekly, except ≈øuch parts of them as may require ≈øecrecy, and the yeas and nays of the members on any que≈øtion, ≈øhall, at the de≈øire of any two of them, be entered on the journals.
The doors of each Hou≈øe and of committees of the whole, ≈øhall be open, unle≈øs when the bu≈øine≈øs ≈øhall be ≈øuch as ought to be kept ≈øecret.
Neither Hou≈øe ≈øhall, without the con≈øent of the other, adjourn for more than three days; nor to any other place than that in which the two Hou≈øes ≈øhall be ≈øitting.

The members of the General A≈ø≈øembly, and the electors of the Senate, ≈øhall receive from the Public Trea≈øury, a compen≈øation for their ≈øervices, which for the pre≈øent ≈øhall be ≈øix ≈øhillings a day during their attendance on, going to, and returning from the Legi≈ølature, and the place for choo≈øing the Senators; but the ≈øame may be increa≈øed or dimini≈øhed by law, if circum≈øtances ≈øhall require it, but no alteration ≈øhall be made, to take effect during the exi≈øtence of the Legi≈ølature, which ≈øhall make ≈øuch alteration: They ≈øhall in all ca≈øes except trea≈øon, felony, breach or ≈øurety of the peace, be privileged from arre≈øt, during their attendance at the ≈øe≈ø≈øion of the re≈øpective Hou≈øes; and at the place for choo≈øing Senators, and in going to and returning from the ≈øame: and for any ≈øpeech or debate in either Hou≈øe, they ≈øhall not be que≈øtioned in any other place.

No Senator or Repre≈øentative ≈øhall, during the time for which he ≈øhall have been elected, or for one year afterwards, be appointed to any civil office under this State, which ≈øhall have been created, or the emoluments of which ≈øhall have been increa≈øed, during the time ≈øuch Senator or Repre≈øentative was in office: Provided that no member of the fir≈øt Legi≈ølature which ≈øhall be a≈ø≈øembled under this Con≈øtitution ≈øhall be precluded from being appointed to any office which may have been created, during his time of ≈øervice in the ≈øaid Legi≈ølature; and no Mini≈øter of religious ≈øociety, member of Congre≈øs, or other per≈øon holding any office of profit under the United States, or this Commonwealth, except Attornies at Law, Ju≈øtices of the Peace, Militia Officers and Coroners, ≈øhall be a member of either Hou≈øe, during his continuance to act as a mini≈øter, in Congre≈øs, or in office.
When vacancies happen in the Hou≈øe of Repre≈øentatives, the Speaker ≈øhall i≈ø≈øue writs of election to fill ≈øuch vacancies.
All bills for rai≈øing Revenue, ≈øhall originate in the Hou≈øe of Repre≈øentatives, but the Senate may propo≈øe amendments as in other bills.

Each Senator, Repre≈øentative and Sheriff ≈øhall, before he be permitted to act as ≈øuch, take an oath, or make affirmation, that he hath not directly or indirectly given or promi≈øed any bribe or treat to procure his election to ≈øaid office, and every per≈øon ≈øhall be di≈øqualified from ≈øerving as a Senator, Repre≈øentative or Sheriff, for the term for which he ≈øhall have been elected, who ≈øhall be convicted of having given or offered any bribe or treat, or canva≈ø≈øed for the ≈øaid office.

Every bill which ≈øhall have pa≈ø≈øed both Hou≈øes, ≈øhall be pre≈øented to the Governor; if he approve, he ≈øhall ≈øign it, but if he ≈øhall not approve, he ≈øhall return it with his objections, to the Hou≈øe in which it ≈øhall have originated, who ≈øhall enter the objections at large upon their journals, and proceed to recon≈øider it; if after ≈øuch recon≈øideration two thirds of that Hou≈øe ≈øhall agree to pa≈øs the bill, it ≈øhall be ≈øent with the objections to the other Hou≈øe, by which likewi≈øe it ≈øhall be recon≈øidered, and if approved by two thirds of that Hou≈øe, it ≈øhall be a law: But in ≈øuch ca≈øes, the votes of both Hou≈øes ≈øhall be determined by yeas and
nays, and the names of the per≈øons voting for or again≈øt the bill, ≈øhall be entered on the journals of each Hou≈øe re≈øpectively; if any bill ≈øhall not be returned by the Governor within ten days, Sundays excepted, after it ≈øhall have been pre≈øented to him, it ≈øhall be a law in like manner as if he had ≈øigned it: unle≈øs the General A≈ø≈øembly by their adjournment prevent its return, in which ca≈øe it ≈øhall be a law, unle≈øs ≈øent back within three days after their next meeting.

Every order, re≈øolution, or vote, to which the concurrence of both Hou≈øes may be nece≈ø≈øary, except on a que≈øtion of adjournment, ≈øhall be pre≈øented to the Governor, and before it ≈øhall take effect, be approved by him; or being di≈øapproved, ≈øhall be repa≈ø≈øed by two thirds of both Hou≈øes, according to the rules and limitations pre≈øcribed in ca≈øe of a bill.

div.head: ARTICLE II.
div.p: THE Supreme Executive power of this Commonwealth ≈øhall be ve≈øted in a Governor.

The Governor ≈øhall be cho≈øen by the electors of the Senate, at the ≈øame time, at the ≈øame place, and in the ≈øame manner, that they are herein directed to elect Senators, and the ≈øaid electors ≈øhall make return of their proceedings in the choice of a Governor, to the Secretary for the time being.
The Governor ≈øhall hold his office during four years from the fir≈øt of June next en≈øuing his election.

He ≈øhall be at lea≈øt thirty years of age, and have been a citizen and inhabitant of this ≈øtate at lea≈øt two years next before his election, unle≈øs he ≈øhall have been ab≈øent on public bu≈øine≈øs of the United States, or of this ≈øtate.
No Member of Congre≈øs, or per≈øon holding any office under the United States, or this ≈øtate, ≈øhall exerci≈øe the office of Governor.
The Governor ≈øhall, at ≈øtated times, receive for his ≈øervices a compen≈øation, which ≈øhall neither be increa≈øed nor dimini≈øhed during the period for which he ≈øhall have been elected.

He ≈øhall be Commander in Chief of the Army and Navy of this Commonwealth, and of the Militia, except
when they ≈øhall be called into the ≈øervice of the United States.

He ≈øhall nominate, and by and with the advice and con≈øent of the Senate, appoint all officers, who≈øe offices are e≈øtabli≈øhed by this Con≈øtitution, or ≈øhall be e≈øtabli≈øhed by law, and who≈øe appointments are not herein otherwi≈øe provided for, but no per≈øon ≈øhall be appointed to an office within any county, who ≈øhall not have been a citizen or inhabitant therein one year next before his appointment, if the county ≈øhall have been ≈øo long erected, but if it ≈øhall not have been ≈øo long erected, then within the limits of the county or counties out of which it ≈øhall have been taken.
The Governor ≈øhall have power to fill up all vacancies, that may happen during the rece≈øs of the Senate, by granting commi≈ø≈øions, which ≈øhall expire at the end of their next ≈øe≈ø≈øion.

He ≈øhall have power to remit ≈øines and forfeitures, and grant reprieves and pardons, except in ca≈øes of impeachment; in ca≈øes of trea≈øon, he ≈øhall have power to grant reprieves until the end of the next ≈øe≈ø≈øion of the General A≈ø≈øembly, in whom the power of pardoning ≈øhall be ve≈øted.
He may require information in writing from the Officers in the Executive Department upon any ≈øubject relating to the duties of their re≈øpective offices.
He ≈øhall, from time to time, give to the General A≈ø≈øembly, information of the ≈øtate of the Commonwealth, and recommend to their con≈øideration, ≈øuch mea≈øures as he ≈øhall judge expedient.

He may, on extraordinary occa≈øions, convene the General A≈ø≈øembly, and in ca≈øe of di≈øagreement between the two Hou≈øes, with re≈øpect to the time of adjournment, adjourn them to ≈øuch time as he ≈øhall think proper, not exceeding four months.
He ≈øhall take care that the laws be faithfully executed.

In ca≈øe of the death or re≈øignation of the Governor, or of his removal from office, the Speaker of the Senate ≈øhall exerci≈øe the office of Gover ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ , until another ≈øhall be duly qualified.

An Attorney-General ≈øhall be appointed and commi≈ø≈øioned during good behaviour; who ≈øhall appear for the Commonwealth in all criminal pro≈øecutions, and in all civil ca≈øes, in which be Commonwealth ≈øhall be intere≈øted in
